SEARCH
Package com.diploma.inno.controller

Class DashboardController

java.lang.Object
com.diploma.inno.controller.DashboardController
@RestController @RequestMapping("/api/dashboard") public class DashboardController extends Object
REST API controller for the CI Anomaly Detector dashboard functionality.

This controller serves as the primary REST interface for a comprehensive Jenkins CI/CD monitoring and anomaly detection system. It provides endpoints for accessing real-time build data, AI-powered analysis results, security anomaly detection, and dashboard analytics.

Base URL: /api/dashboard

System Architecture Overview:

  • Data Sources: Jenkins REST API, PostgreSQL database with JSONB storage
  • AI Integration: Machine learning analysis stored in chat_messages table
  • Caching Strategy: Materialized views and computed metrics tables
  • Sync Process: Scheduled 15-minute Jenkins job synchronization

Database Schema Dependencies:

  • chat_messages: Core table storing AI analysis results and build logs in JSONB format
  • recent_job_builds: Materialized view for recent build metrics and health status
  • security_anomaly_counts: Aggregated security anomaly statistics by job and time range
  • active_build_counts: Real-time active build statistics by job filter
  • job_counts: Job activity metrics grouped by time boundaries
  • build_anomaly_summary: Aggregated anomaly data for trend analysis

Core Functionality Categories:

  • Build Monitoring: Real-time build status, recent builds, active build tracking
  • Anomaly Detection: AI-powered security anomaly identification and classification
  • Analytics & Visualization: Chart data for trends, severity distributions, metrics
  • Job Management: Job discovery, status filtering, build triggering
  • AI Insights: Machine learning analysis, recommendations, risk scoring
  • Log Analysis: Paginated build log retrieval and processing status

Data Processing Flow:

  1. Jenkins Integration: Real-time data fetching via jenkins-rest library
  2. AI Analysis: Build logs processed and results stored as JSONB in chat_messages
  3. Data Aggregation: Complex SQL queries with CTEs for dashboard metrics
  4. Caching Layer: Materialized views and computed tables for performance
  5. API Response: DTO mapping and JSON serialization for frontend consumption

Response Format Standards:

  • Structured DTOs: Type-safe data transfer objects with computed timestamps
  • Chart Data: Standardized format for Chart.js and similar visualization libraries
  • Paginated Results: Consistent pagination with total counts and metadata
  • Error Responses: Structured error information with context

Performance Optimizations:

  • Database Projections: Custom projection interfaces to minimize data transfer
  • Query Optimization: Complex CTEs with window functions for efficient aggregation
  • JSONB Operations: Native PostgreSQL JSONB queries for AI analysis data
  • Pagination: LIMIT/OFFSET for large datasets with configurable page sizes

Security Considerations:

  • ‚ö†Ô∏è CRITICAL: No authentication/authorization currently implemented
  • üîí RECOMMENDATION: Implement Spring Security with role-based access control
  • üõ°Ô∏è INPUT VALIDATION: Add @Valid annotations and parameter validation
  • üìù AUDIT LOGGING: Consider implementing audit trails for sensitive operations

Error Handling Strategy:

  • 404 Not Found: When requested data doesn't exist in database
  • 500 Internal Server Error: For JSON processing failures and database errors
  • 400 Bad Request: For invalid parameters or malformed requests
  • Graceful Degradation: Empty responses instead of exceptions where appropriate
Since:
1.0
Version:

  • Method Details

    • getAllRecentBuilds

      @GetMapping("/recentJobBuilds") public org.springframework.http.ResponseEntity<List<RecentJobBuildDTO>> getAllRecentBuilds()
      Retrieves recent build information for all Jenkins jobs.

      Database Query Process:

      1. Queries recent_job_builds materialized view
      2. Filters by jobName = "all" to include all jobs
      3. Orders by raw_timestamp DESC for most recent builds first
      4. Maps to RecentJobBuildProjection interface
      5. Converts to RecentJobBuildDTO with computed timestamps

      Endpoint: GET /api/dashboard/recentJobBuilds

      Response Data Structure:

      Each build entry includes:

      • jobName: Display name of the Jenkins job
      • buildId: Unique build number from Jenkins
      • healthStatus: Computed status (SUCCESS, FAILURE, WARNING, CRITICAL)
      • anomalyCount: Number of AI-detected anomalies in the build
      • timeAgo: Human-readable relative time (e.g., "2 hours ago")
      • rawTimestamp: ISO timestamp for precise sorting
      • computedAt: When the materialized view was last refreshed
      • originalJobName: Original Jenkins job name for API calls

      Health Status Calculation:

      Status is computed based on anomaly severity in the AI analysis:

      • CRITICAL: Contains CRITICAL or HIGH severity anomalies
      • WARNING: Contains MEDIUM severity or multiple anomalies
      • SUCCESS: No significant anomalies detected

      Performance Notes:

      • Data served from materialized view for fast response times
      • View refreshed periodically via scheduled tasks
      • Typical response includes 10-50 recent builds across all jobs

      Use Cases:

      • Dashboard overview displaying recent build activity
      • Build health monitoring across all projects
      • Quick identification of failed or problematic builds
      • Anomaly detection summary for recent builds
      Returns:
      ResponseEntity containing a list of RecentJobBuildDTO objects representing recent builds across all jobs, with HTTP 200 OK status
      See Also:
      • RecentJobBuildDTO
      • DashboardService.getRecentJobBuildsByJobName(String)
      • RecentJobBuildProjection

    • getRecentBuildsByJobName

      @GetMapping("/recentJobBuilds/{jobName}") public org.springframework.http.ResponseEntity<List<RecentJobBuildDTO>> getRecentBuildsByJobName(@PathVariable String jobName)
      Retrieves recent build information for a specific Jenkins job.

      Database Query Process:

      1. Queries recent_job_builds materialized view
      2. Filters WHERE job_name = :jobName for specific job
      3. Orders by raw_timestamp DESC for chronological order
      4. Returns List<RecentJobBuildProjection> mapped to DTOs

      Endpoint: GET /api/dashboard/recentJobBuilds/{jobName}

      Path Parameters:

      • jobName: The exact name of the Jenkins job to query (case-sensitive)

      Job Name Handling:

      • Must match the original Jenkins job name exactly
      • Special characters and spaces are preserved
      • URL encoding is handled automatically by Spring
      • Empty or null jobName returns empty list

      Response Data:

      Returns the same structure as getAllRecentBuilds() but filtered to only include builds from the specified job. Typical response includes 5-20 recent builds for the job depending on build frequency.

      Data Freshness:

      • Data sourced from materialized view refreshed every 15 minutes
      • computedAt timestamp indicates last refresh time
      • May not include builds triggered in the last few minutes

      Use Cases:

      • Job-specific build history analysis
      • Monitoring build trends for a particular project
      • Detailed anomaly tracking for specific jobs
      • Project-focused dashboard views

      Example Usage:

      GET /api/dashboard/recentJobBuilds/my-web-app
GET /api/dashboard/recentJobBuilds/backend-service
GET /api/dashboard/recentJobBuilds/My%20Project%20With%20Spaces
      Parameters:
      jobName - the name of the Jenkins job to retrieve recent builds for
      Returns:
      ResponseEntity containing a list of RecentJobBuildDTO objects for the specified job, with HTTP 200 OK status
      See Also:
      • RecentJobBuildDTO
      • DashboardService.getRecentJobBuildsByJobName(String)
      • RecentJobBuildProjection

    • getAllSecurityAnomalies

      @GetMapping("/securityAnomalies") public org.springframework.http.ResponseEntity<SecurityAnomalyCountDTO> getAllSecurityAnomalies()
      Retrieves security anomaly count summary for all jobs with default time range.

      Database Query Process:

      1. Queries security_anomaly_counts aggregated table
      2. Filters WHERE job_filter = 'all' AND time_range = '7 days'
      3. Returns SecurityAnomalyCountProjection mapped to DTO
      4. Includes computed timestamp from last aggregation run

      Endpoint: GET /api/dashboard/securityAnomalies

      Default Parameters:

      • Job Filter: "all" (includes all jobs)
      • Time Range: "7 days" (last week)

      Response Data Structure:

      • jobFilter: The filter applied ("all")
      • anomalyCount: Total number of security anomalies detected
      • timeRange: The time period analyzed ("7 days")
      • computedAt: Timestamp when the aggregation was last calculated

      Security Anomaly Classification:

      Includes various types of security-related issues detected by AI analysis:

      • Dependency Vulnerabilities: Known CVEs in project dependencies
      • Security Scan Failures: Failed security scans or policy violations
      • Authentication Issues: Authentication/authorization problems
      • Suspicious Patterns: Unusual build patterns or behaviors
      • Code Quality Security: Security-related code quality violations
      • Secret Exposure: Potential secrets or credentials in logs

      Data Aggregation Process:

      • AI analysis results from chat_messages table are processed
      • JSONB content is parsed for anomaly severity and type
      • Security-specific anomalies are filtered and counted
      • Results are aggregated by job filter and time range
      • Computed metrics are stored in security_anomaly_counts table

      Use Cases:

      • Security dashboard overview widgets
      • High-level security health monitoring
      • Trend analysis for security improvements
      • Executive reporting on security posture

      Performance Notes:

      • Data served from pre-computed aggregation table
      • Aggregations refreshed periodically via scheduled tasks
      • Fast response time due to materialized data
      Returns:
      ResponseEntity containing SecurityAnomalyCountDTO with anomaly count data, or HTTP 404 Not Found if no data is available
      See Also:
      • SecurityAnomalyCountDTO
      • DashboardService.getSecurityAnomalyCountByJobFilterAndTimeRange(String, String)
      • SecurityAnomalyCountProjection

    • getSecurityAnomaliesByJobFilterAndTimeRange

      @GetMapping("/securityAnomalies/{jobFilter}") public org.springframework.http.ResponseEntity<SecurityAnomalyCountDTO> getSecurityAnomaliesByJobFilterAndTimeRange(@PathVariable String jobFilter, @RequestParam String timeRange)
      Retrieves security anomaly count for specific job filter and time range.

      Database Query Process:

      1. Queries security_anomaly_counts aggregated table
      2. Filters WHERE job_filter = :jobFilter AND time_range = :timeRange
      3. Returns SecurityAnomalyCountProjection with computed metrics
      4. Handles null/empty parameters with validation

      Endpoint: GET /api/dashboard/securityAnomalies/{jobFilter}

      Path Parameters:

      • jobFilter: Job name or "all" for all jobs

      Query Parameters:

      • timeRange: Time period to analyze (required)

      Supported Time Ranges:

      • "7 days": Last week of build activity
      • "14 days": Last two weeks
      • "30 days": Last month
      • "90 days": Last quarter
      • "1 year": Last year

      Job Filter Options:

      • "all": Include all Jenkins jobs in the analysis
      • Specific job name: Filter to a single job (exact match)
      • Job pattern: May support pattern matching (implementation dependent)

      Parameter Validation:

      • Empty or null jobFilter defaults to "unknown" with 0 count
      • Empty or null timeRange defaults to "unknown" with 0 count
      • Invalid combinations return default DTO with error indicators

      Example Usage:

      GET /api/dashboard/securityAnomalies/my-web-app?timeRange=30%20days
GET /api/dashboard/securityAnomalies/all?timeRange=7%20days
GET /api/dashboard/securityAnomalies/backend-service?timeRange=90%20days

      Use Cases:

      • Project-specific security analysis
      • Historical security trend analysis
      • Comparative security assessment across time periods
      • Focused security monitoring for critical projects

      Response Handling:

      • Always returns HTTP 200 OK (no 404 for this endpoint)
      • Missing data returns DTO with 0 count and error indicators
      • Graceful degradation for invalid parameters
      Parameters:
      jobFilter - the job name to filter by, or "all" for all jobs
      timeRange - the time period to analyze (e.g., "7 days", "30 days")
      Returns:
      ResponseEntity containing SecurityAnomalyCountDTO with filtered anomaly count data, with HTTP 200 OK status
      See Also:
      • SecurityAnomalyCountDTO
      • DashboardService.getSecurityAnomalyCountByJobFilterAndTimeRange(String, String)
      • SecurityAnomalyCountProjection

    • getAllActiveBuilds

      @GetMapping("/activeBuilds") public org.springframework.http.ResponseEntity<ActiveBuildCountDTO> getAllActiveBuilds()
      Retrieves the total count of currently active builds across all Jenkins jobs.

      Database Query Process:

      1. Queries active_build_counts aggregated table
      2. Filters WHERE job_filter = 'all' for system-wide count
      3. Returns ActiveBuildCountProjection mapped to DTO
      4. Includes computed timestamp from last aggregation run

      Endpoint: GET /api/dashboard/activeBuilds

      Response Data Structure:

      • jobFilter: "all" (indicates all jobs are included)
      • activeBuilds: Total number of builds currently running
      • computedAt: Timestamp when the count was calculated

      Active Build Definition:

      Includes builds in the following states:

      • Currently Executing: Builds actively running build steps
      • Queue Waiting: Builds waiting in the Jenkins build queue
      • Paused/Manual: Builds paused for manual intervention
      • Starting Up: Builds that are initializing or starting

      Data Aggregation Process:

      • Real-time Jenkins API calls to check build status
      • Build queue analysis for pending builds
      • Job status evaluation across all configured jobs
      • Results cached in active_build_counts table
      • Periodic refresh to maintain accuracy

      Use Cases:

      • System load monitoring and capacity planning
      • Dashboard widgets showing current activity
      • Performance analysis and bottleneck identification
      • Resource utilization tracking

      Data Freshness:

      • Data typically cached with short TTL (15-30 seconds)
      • Balance between real-time accuracy and system performance
      • computedAt timestamp indicates last refresh time
      Returns:
      ResponseEntity containing ActiveBuildCountDTO with total active build count, or HTTP 404 Not Found if no data is available
      See Also:
      • ActiveBuildCountDTO
      • DashboardService.getTotalActiveBuildCount()
      • ActiveBuildCountProjection

    • getActiveBuildsByJobFilter

      @GetMapping("/activeBuilds/{jobFilter}") public org.springframework.http.ResponseEntity<ActiveBuildCountDTO> getActiveBuildsByJobFilter(@PathVariable String jobFilter)
      Retrieves the count of active builds filtered by job name or pattern.

      Database Query Process:

      1. Queries active_build_counts aggregated table
      2. Filters WHERE job_filter = :jobFilter for specific job/pattern
      3. Returns ActiveBuildCountProjection with filtered metrics
      4. Handles validation and error cases gracefully

      Endpoint: GET /api/dashboard/activeBuilds/{jobFilter}

      Path Parameters:

      • jobFilter: Job name, pattern, or "all" for all jobs

      Job Filter Options:

      • Specific job name: Count active builds for a single job
      • "all": Count active builds across all jobs (same as getAllActiveBuilds())
      • Pattern matching: May support wildcards or regex (implementation dependent)

      Response Data Structure:

      • jobFilter: The filter that was applied
      • activeBuilds: Number of active builds matching the filter
      • computedAt: Timestamp when the count was calculated

      Parameter Validation:

      • Null or empty jobFilter returns DTO with "error" filter and 0 count
      • Invalid job names return DTO with "error" filter and 0 count
      • Missing data returns DTO with "error" filter and 0 count
      • Graceful degradation prevents exceptions

      Example Usage:

      GET /api/dashboard/activeBuilds/my-web-app
GET /api/dashboard/activeBuilds/backend-*
GET /api/dashboard/activeBuilds/all

      Use Cases:

      • Project-specific build monitoring
      • Team-focused dashboard views
      • Load balancing and resource allocation
      • Build queue analysis for specific projects
      Parameters:
      jobFilter - the job name, pattern, or "all" to filter active builds by
      Returns:
      ResponseEntity containing ActiveBuildCountDTO with filtered active build count, or HTTP 404 Not Found if no data is available
      See Also:
      • ActiveBuildCountDTO
      • DashboardService.getActiveBuildCountByJobFilter(String)
      • ActiveBuildCountProjection

    • getTotalJobs

      @GetMapping("/totalJobs/{timeBoundary}") public org.springframework.http.ResponseEntity<JobCountDTO> getTotalJobs(@PathVariable String timeBoundary)
      Retrieves the total count of Jenkins jobs within a specified time boundary.

      Database Query Process:

      1. Queries job_counts aggregated table
      2. Filters WHERE time_boundary = :timeBoundary for specific period
      3. Returns JobCountProjection mapped to DTO
      4. Includes computed timestamp from last aggregation run

      Endpoint: GET /api/dashboard/totalJobs/{timeBoundary}

      Path Parameters:

      • timeBoundary: The time period to analyze job activity within

      Supported Time Boundaries:

      • "today": Jobs that had activity today (last 24 hours)
      • "week": Jobs active in the last 7 days
      • "month": Jobs active in the last 30 days
      • "quarter": Jobs active in the last 90 days
      • "year": Jobs active in the last 365 days
      • "all": All jobs regardless of activity

      Response Data Structure:

      • timeBoundary: The time period that was analyzed
      • totalJobs: Number of jobs with activity in the specified period
      • computedAt: Timestamp when the count was calculated

      Job Activity Definition:

      A job is considered "active" within a time boundary if it has:

      • Build Execution: Executed at least one build in the period
      • Configuration Changes: Been modified or reconfigured
      • Trigger Events: Had any interaction or trigger event
      • Status Updates: Any status or metadata changes

      Data Aggregation Process:

      • Analysis of chat_messages table for job activity
      • Jenkins API calls for job metadata and build history
      • Time-based filtering using timestamp comparisons
      • Results cached in job_counts table by time boundary
      • Periodic refresh to maintain accuracy

      Use Cases:

      • Infrastructure utilization analysis
      • Growth tracking and capacity planning
      • Identifying dormant or unused jobs
      • Executive reporting on CI/CD adoption

      Example Usage:

      GET /api/dashboard/totalJobs/today
GET /api/dashboard/totalJobs/week
GET /api/dashboard/totalJobs/month
      Parameters:
      timeBoundary - the time period to count job activity within
      Returns:
      ResponseEntity containing JobCountDTO with job count data, or HTTP 404 Not Found if no data is available
      See Also:
      • JobCountDTO
      • DashboardService.getJobCountByTimeBoundary(String)
      • JobCountProjection

    • getBuildSummary

      @GetMapping("/builds/{conversationId}/{buildNumber}") public Map<String,Object> getBuildSummary(@PathVariable String conversationId, @PathVariable Integer buildNumber)
      Retrieves comprehensive build summary information for a specific build.

      Database Query Process:

      1. Queries chat_messages table for AI analysis results
      2. Filters WHERE conversation_id = :conversationId AND build_number = :buildNumber
      3. Searches for message_type = 'ASSISTANT' with build summary data
      4. Parses JSONB content field for structured build information
      5. Maps to BuildSummaryDTO or returns status information

      Endpoint: GET /api/dashboard/builds/{conversationId}/{buildNumber}

      Path Parameters:

      • conversationId: The Jenkins job name (used as conversation identifier)
      • buildNumber: The specific build number to retrieve

      Response Structure:

      Returns a Map containing:

      • hasAiData: Boolean indicating if AI analysis is available
      • data: BuildSummaryDTO with build details (if AI data exists)
      • message: Error or status message (if AI data doesn't exist)

      Build Summary Data (when available):

      • jobName: Name of the Jenkins job
      • buildId: Build number
      • healthStatus: SUCCESS, FAILURE, UNSTABLE, or ABORTED
      • buildSummary: AI-generated summary of the build
      • buildStartedTime: When the build was initiated
      • buildDuration: How long the build took
      • regressionDetected: Whether performance regression was found

      AI Analysis Integration:

      • AI analysis is triggered asynchronously after build completion
      • Results stored as JSONB in chat_messages.content field
      • Analysis includes log parsing, anomaly detection, and summary generation
      • If hasAiData is false, analysis may still be in progress

      JSONB Content Structure:

      The AI analysis content includes:

      • Build metadata and timing information
      • Anomaly detection results with severity levels
      • Performance regression analysis
      • Security vulnerability assessments
      • Human-readable build summary

      Example Usage:

      GET /api/dashboard/builds/my-web-app/123
GET /api/dashboard/builds/backend-service/456

      Use Cases:

      • Detailed build analysis and reporting
      • Build summary display in dashboards
      • AI-powered build insights and recommendations
      • Build performance and regression analysis
      Parameters:
      conversationId - the Jenkins job name (conversation identifier)
      buildNumber - the specific build number to retrieve summary for
      Returns:
      Map containing build summary data with AI analysis results, or status information if data is not available
      See Also:
      • BuildSummaryDTO
      • DashboardService.getBuildSummary(String, Integer)

    • getLogsTracker

      @GetMapping("/builds/{jobName}/{buildId}/logs-tracker") public Map<String,Object> getLogsTracker(@PathVariable String jobName, @PathVariable int buildId)
      Retrieves build log tracking information for a specific build.

      Database Query Process:

      1. Queries chat_messages table for log processing status
      2. Counts USER messages WHERE conversation_id = :jobName AND build_number = :buildId
      3. Filters for messages without 'instructions' field in JSONB content
      4. Calculates received vs expected log count (expected = 14)
      5. Returns processing status and completion percentage

      Endpoint: GET /api/dashboard/builds/{jobName}/{buildId}/logs-tracker

      Path Parameters:

      • jobName: The name of the Jenkins job
      • buildId: The specific build number to track logs for

      Response Data Structure:

      Returns a Map containing log tracking information:

      • received: Number of log entries processed (max 14)
      • expected: Expected number of log entries (always 14)
      • status: "Complete" if received >= 14, "In Progress" otherwise

      Log Processing Pipeline:

      • Log Ingestion: Build logs are fetched from Jenkins API
      • Chunking: Logs are split into manageable chunks
      • Storage: Each chunk stored as USER message in chat_messages
      • AI Processing: Logs are analyzed for anomalies and insights
      • Status Tracking: Progress tracked via message count

      Expected Log Count Logic:

      • System expects 14 log chunks per build for complete analysis
      • Each chunk represents a portion of the build log
      • Fewer chunks may indicate incomplete log processing
      • Status "Complete" when all expected chunks are received

      JSONB Content Filtering:

      • Excludes messages with 'instructions' field (system messages)
      • Counts only actual log content messages
      • Ensures accurate tracking of log processing progress

      Use Cases:

      • Monitoring log analysis progress
      • Debugging log processing issues
      • Performance analysis of log processing workflows
      • Build log health monitoring

      Example Response:

      {
  "received": 14,
  "expected": 14,
  "status": "Complete"
}
      Parameters:
      jobName - the name of the Jenkins job
      buildId - the build number to track logs for
      Returns:
      Map containing log tracking information and metadata
      See Also:
      • DashboardService.getLogsTracker(String, int)

    • getRiskScore

      @GetMapping("/builds/{conversationId}/{buildNumber}/risk-score") public Map<String,Object> getRiskScore(@PathVariable String conversationId, @PathVariable Integer buildNumber) throws com.fasterxml.jackson.core.JsonProcessingException
      Retrieves AI-calculated risk score information for a specific build.

      Database Query Process:

      1. Queries chat_messages table for AI risk analysis
      2. Filters WHERE message_type = 'ASSISTANT' AND conversation_id = :conversationId AND build_number = :buildNumber
      3. Extracts JSONB content->'riskScore' object using jsonb_build_object
      4. Parses risk score, change, level, and previous score
      5. Maps to RiskScoreDTO or returns error information

      Endpoint: GET /api/dashboard/builds/{conversationId}/{buildNumber}/risk-score

      Path Parameters:

      • conversationId: The Jenkins job name (conversation identifier)
      • buildNumber: The specific build number to get risk score for

      Response Data Structure:

      Returns a Map containing risk assessment information:

      • hasData: Boolean indicating if risk score data is available
      • data: RiskScoreDTO with risk metrics (if available)
      • message: Error or status message (if data unavailable)

      Risk Score Data (when available):

      • score: Numerical risk rating (typically 0-100)
      • change: Risk score change from previous build
      • riskLevel: Categorical risk level (LOW, MEDIUM, HIGH, CRITICAL)
      • previousScore: Risk score of the previous build

      Risk Assessment Factors:

      • Security Vulnerabilities: Known CVEs and security anomalies
      • Build Failure Patterns: Historical failure rates and patterns
      • Code Quality Metrics: Technical debt and quality violations
      • Test Coverage: Test failure rates and coverage metrics
      • Dependency Issues: Outdated or vulnerable dependencies
      • Performance Regressions: Build time and performance issues

      Risk Level Classification:

      • LOW (0-25): Minimal risk, good build health
      • MEDIUM (26-50): Moderate risk, some issues to address
      • HIGH (51-75): Significant risk, requires attention
      • CRITICAL (76-100): Severe risk, immediate action needed

      JSONB Query Structure:

      SELECT jsonb_build_object(
  'score', (content->'riskScore'->>'score')::integer,
  'change', (content->'riskScore'->>'change')::integer,
  'riskLevel', content->'riskScore'->>'riskLevel',
  'previousScore', (content->'riskScore'->>'previousScore')::integer
) FROM chat_messages WHERE ...

      Error Handling:

      • JsonProcessingException: Error parsing risk score data
      • Missing Data: No AI analysis available for the build
      • Invalid Format: Malformed JSONB content structure

      Use Cases:

      • Build quality assessment and gating
      • Security risk monitoring
      • Trend analysis for build health
      • Automated decision making for deployments
      Parameters:
      conversationId - the Jenkins job name (conversation identifier)
      buildNumber - the specific build number to get risk score for
      Returns:
      Map containing risk score data and assessment details
      Throws:
      com.fasterxml.jackson.core.JsonProcessingException - if there's an error processing the risk score data
      See Also:
      • DashboardService.getRiskScore(String, Integer)
      • RiskScoreDTO

    • getAllLogs

      @GetMapping(value="/builds/{jobName}/{buildId}/logs", produces="application/json") public List<Object> getAllLogs(@PathVariable String jobName, @PathVariable int buildId, @RequestParam(defaultValue="0") int page, @RequestParam(defaultValue="100") int size)
      Retrieves paginated build logs for a specific Jenkins build.

      Database Query Process:

      1. Queries chat_messages table for build log content
      2. Filters WHERE message_type = 'USER' AND conversation_id = :jobName AND build_number = :buildId
      3. Excludes messages with 'instructions' field using NOT jsonb_exists(content, 'instructions')
      4. Orders by timestamp for chronological log sequence
      5. Applies LIMIT :size OFFSET :offset for pagination
      6. Parses JSONB content field to Object using ObjectMapper

      Endpoint: GET /api/dashboard/builds/{jobName}/{buildId}/logs

      Path Parameters:

      • jobName: The name of the Jenkins job
      • buildId: The specific build number to retrieve logs for

      Query Parameters:

      • page: Page number for pagination (default: 0, 0-based)
      • size: Number of log entries per page (default: 100)

      Response Format:

      Returns a List of Objects containing log entries with:

      • Log Content: Parsed JSONB content from chat_messages
      • Timestamp Information: When the log entry was created
      • Structured Data: JSON objects with log metadata
      • Build Context: Information about the build step or phase

      Pagination Implementation:

      • Offset Calculation: offset = page * size
      • Page Size Limits: Recommended max size: 1000 for performance
      • Zero-based Indexing: First page is page=0
      • Chronological Order: Logs ordered by timestamp ASC

      JSONB Content Processing:

      • Each log entry stored as JSONB in chat_messages.content field
      • ObjectMapper.readValue() converts JSONB to Java Object
      • Malformed JSON entries are filtered out (null values removed)
      • Error logging for failed JSON parsing attempts

      Log Entry Structure:

      Typical log entry contains:

      • Build step information and phase
      • Console output and command results
      • Timestamps and duration data
      • Error messages and stack traces
      • Plugin output and tool results

      Performance Considerations:

      • Large log files are automatically chunked during ingestion
      • Pagination prevents memory issues with large builds
      • JSONB indexing optimizes query performance
      • Failed JSON parsing is logged but doesn't break the response

      Use Cases:

      • Build log viewing and analysis
      • Debugging build failures and issues
      • Log search and filtering operations
      • Automated log processing and analysis

      Example Usage:

      GET /api/dashboard/builds/my-web-app/123/logs?page=0&size=50
GET /api/dashboard/builds/backend-service/456/logs?page=2&size=200
      Parameters:
      jobName - the name of the Jenkins job
      buildId - the build number to retrieve logs for
      page - the page number for pagination (0-based)
      size - the number of log entries per page
      Returns:
      List of Objects containing paginated log entries
      See Also:
      • DashboardService.getAllLogs(String, int, int, int)

    • rerunBuild

      @PostMapping("/builds/{jobName}/{buildId}/rerun") public Map<String,String> rerunBuild(@PathVariable String jobName, @PathVariable int buildId)
      Triggers a new build for the specified Jenkins job.

      Jenkins API Integration Process:

      1. Calls JenkinsService.rerunBuild() with job name and build ID
      2. Uses jenkins-rest library to make API call to Jenkins server
      3. Executes jenkinsClient.api().jobsApi().build("", jobName)
      4. Queues new build with current job configuration
      5. Returns confirmation message with job name

      Endpoint: POST /api/dashboard/builds/{jobName}/{buildId}/rerun

      Path Parameters:

      • jobName: The name of the Jenkins job to trigger
      • buildId: The build number (used for reference, new build will get next available number)

      Build Trigger Process:

      1. Validation: Checks if job exists and is accessible
      2. Permission Check: Verifies Jenkins user has build permissions
      3. Queue Submission: Submits build request to Jenkins queue
      4. Response Generation: Returns confirmation message

      Response Format:

      Returns a Map containing:

      • message: Confirmation message indicating build was triggered

      Build Behavior:

      • Configuration: New build uses the current job configuration
      • Parameters: Build parameters are inherited from job defaults
      • Queuing: Build is queued and will start when resources are available
      • Independence: Original build data and logs remain unchanged
      • Build Number: New build gets the next sequential build number

      Jenkins API Call Details:

      • Endpoint: POST /job/{jobName}/build
      • Authentication: Uses configured Jenkins credentials
      • Folder Path: Empty string "" for root-level jobs
      • Error Handling: Exceptions logged but don't prevent response

      Use Cases:

      • Retrying failed builds after fixing issues
      • Manual build triggering for testing
      • Re-running builds with updated dependencies
      • Emergency builds for hotfixes

      Security Considerations:

      • ‚ö†Ô∏è WARNING: No authentication/authorization currently implemented
      • üîí RECOMMENDATION: Add proper access controls for build triggering
      • üìù AUDIT: Consider logging build trigger events for audit trails
      • üõ°Ô∏è PERMISSIONS: Ensure Jenkins user has minimal required permissions

      Error Scenarios:

      • Job Not Found: Jenkins returns 404 for non-existent jobs
      • Permission Denied: Jenkins returns 403 for insufficient permissions
      • Server Unavailable: Network or Jenkins server issues
      • Queue Full: Jenkins build queue at capacity

      Example Usage:

       POST /api/dashboard/builds/my-web-app/123/rerun
 POST /api/dashboard/builds/backend-service/456/rerun
      Parameters:
      jobName - the name of the Jenkins job to trigger a new build for
      buildId - the build number (for reference, new build gets next available number)
      Returns:
      Map containing confirmation message about the triggered build
      See Also:
      • JenkinsService.rerunBuild(String, int)
      • JenkinsClient

    • getJobNames

      @GetMapping("/jobs") public org.springframework.http.ResponseEntity<List<String>> getJobNames()
      Retrieves a list of all Jenkins job names available in the system.

      Database Query Process:

      1. Queries chat_messages table for distinct job names
      2. Executes SELECT DISTINCT job_name WHERE job_name IS NOT NULL
      3. Orders results alphabetically for consistent presentation
      4. Returns List<String> of unique job names

      Endpoint: GET /api/dashboard/jobs

      Response Format:

      Returns a List of Strings containing:

      • Active Job Names: Jobs that have had recent activity
      • Historical Jobs: Jobs with stored analysis data
      • Alphabetical Order: Sorted for consistent UI presentation
      • Non-null Values: Filters out any null or empty job names

      Data Source Analysis:

      • Primary Source: chat_messages table job_name column
      • Data Freshness: Reflects jobs with stored AI analysis results
      • Synchronization: Updated via 15-minute scheduled Jenkins sync
      • Cleanup: Orphaned jobs removed during sync process

      Job Name Characteristics:

      • Case Sensitivity: Preserves original Jenkins job name casing
      • Special Characters: Includes spaces, hyphens, underscores
      • Folder Structure: May include folder paths if applicable
      • Uniqueness: DISTINCT ensures no duplicate entries

      Synchronization Process:

      • Scheduled task runs every 15 minutes (@Scheduled annotation)
      • Fetches current jobs from Jenkins API via JenkinsService
      • Compares with database job names for consistency
      • Removes orphaned jobs (safety check prevents mass deletion)
      • Maintains data integrity between Jenkins and database

      Use Cases:

      • Populating job selection dropdowns in UI
      • System administration and job management
      • Automated job discovery and monitoring setup
      • Integration with external tools and dashboards

      Performance Notes:

      • Fast response due to simple DISTINCT query
      • Minimal data transfer (only job names)
      • Cached at database level for repeated queries
      • Typical response includes 10-100 job names
      Returns:
      ResponseEntity containing a list of all Jenkins job names with HTTP 200 OK status
      See Also:
      • DashboardService.getAllJobNames()

    • getDetectedAnomalies

      @GetMapping("/builds/{jobName}/{buildId}/detected-anomalies") public Map<String,Object> getDetectedAnomalies(@PathVariable String jobName, @PathVariable int buildId, @RequestParam(defaultValue="1") int page, @RequestParam(defaultValue="3") int size)
      Retrieves paginated anomalies detected in a specific build.

      Database Query Process:

      1. Queries chat_messages table for AI analysis results
      2. Uses complex CTE with CROSS JOIN LATERAL to unnest JSONB anomalies array
      3. Filters WHERE message_type = 'ASSISTANT' AND conversation_id = :jobName AND build_number = :buildId
      4. Applies LIMIT :pageSize OFFSET :offset for pagination
      5. Counts total anomalies for pagination metadata
      6. Returns structured response with anomalies and pagination info

      Endpoint: GET /api/dashboard/builds/{jobName}/{buildId}/detected-anomalies

      Path Parameters:

      • jobName: The name of the Jenkins job
      • buildId: The specific build number to retrieve anomalies for

      Query Parameters:

      • page: Page number for pagination (default: 1, 1-based)
      • size: Number of anomalies per page (default: 3)

      Complex SQL Query Structure:

      WITH unnested_anomalies AS (
  SELECT anomaly, position
  FROM chat_messages cm
  CROSS JOIN LATERAL jsonb_array_elements(
    COALESCE(cm.content->'anomalies', '[]'::jsonb)
  ) WITH ORDINALITY AS t(anomaly, position)
  WHERE cm.message_type = 'ASSISTANT'
    AND cm.conversation_id = :conversationId
    AND cm.build_number = :buildNumber
  ORDER BY position
  LIMIT :pageSize OFFSET :offset
),
total_count AS (
  SELECT COUNT(*) AS total FROM ..
)
SELECT COALESCE(jsonb_agg(anomaly ORDER BY position), '[]'::jsonb) AS anomalies,
       (SELECT total FROM total_count) AS total_count
FROM unnested_anomalies

      Response Structure:

      Returns a Map containing:

      • hasData: Boolean indicating if anomalies are available
      • anomalies: List of AnomalyDTO objects for the current page
      • totalCount: Total number of anomalies found
      • pageNumber: Current page number (1-based)
      • pageSize: Number of items per page
      • totalPages: Total number of pages available
      • message: Error message if no data available

      Anomaly Information Structure:

      Each anomaly includes:

      • type: Category of the anomaly (security, performance, quality, etc.)
      • severity: CRITICAL, HIGH, MEDIUM, WARNING, or LOW
      • description: Human-readable description of the issue
      • recommendation: Suggested actions to resolve the issue
      • aiAnalysis: Detailed AI-generated analysis
      • details: Additional technical details and context

      JSONB Array Processing:

      • CROSS JOIN LATERAL unnests JSONB array into individual rows
      • WITH ORDINALITY preserves original array order
      • COALESCE handles cases where anomalies array doesn't exist
      • jsonb_agg reconstructs paginated array for response

      Pagination Implementation:

      • 1-based Page Numbers: Frontend-friendly pagination
      • Offset Calculation: (page - 1) * size
      • Total Count: Separate CTE for accurate pagination metadata
      • Small Page Size: Default 3 items for detailed anomaly display

      Use Cases:

      • Detailed build analysis and issue investigation
      • Security vulnerability assessment
      • Quality assurance and code review processes
      • Automated issue tracking and reporting

      Example Usage:

      GET /api/dashboard/builds/my-web-app/123/detected-anomalies?page=1&size=5
GET /api/dashboard/builds/backend-service/456/detected-anomalies?page=2&size=10
      Parameters:
      jobName - the name of the Jenkins job
      buildId - the build number to retrieve anomalies for
      page - the page number for pagination (1-based)
      size - the number of anomalies per page
      Returns:
      Map containing paginated anomaly data and metadata
      See Also:
      • AnomalyDTO
      • PaginatedAnomaliesDTO
      • DashboardService.getPaginatedAnomalies(String, Integer, Integer, Integer)

    • getAnomalyTrend

      @GetMapping("/anomaly-trend") public ChartDataDTO getAnomalyTrend(@RequestParam(defaultValue="all") String jobFilter, @RequestParam(defaultValue="5") Integer buildCount)
      Retrieves anomaly trend data for chart visualization.

      Database Query Process:

      1. Queries build_anomaly_summary table for trend analysis
      2. Uses complex CTE with ROW_NUMBER() window function for latest builds
      3. Filters by job (WHERE :jobFilter = 'all' OR conversation_id = :jobFilter)
      4. Partitions by conversation_id and orders by timestamp DESC, build_number DESC
      5. Limits to specified buildCount per job for trend analysis
      6. Returns List<Map> with job, build, timestamp, and anomaly_count

      Endpoint: GET /api/dashboard/anomaly-trend

      Query Parameters:

      • jobFilter: Job name or "all" for all jobs (default: "all")
      • buildCount: Number of recent builds to analyze (default: 5, max: 15)

      Complex SQL Query Structure:

      WITH distinct_jobs AS (
  SELECT COUNT(DISTINCT conversation_id) AS total_jobs
  FROM build_anomaly_summary
  WHERE (:jobFilter = 'all' OR conversation_id = :jobFilter)
),
ranked_builds AS (
  SELECT conversation_id AS job, build_number AS build,
         timestamp, total_anomalies AS anomaly_count,
         ROW_NUMBER() OVER (PARTITION BY conversation_id
                           ORDER BY timestamp DESC, build_number DESC) AS rn
  FROM build_anomaly_summary
  WHERE (:jobFilter = 'all' OR conversation_id = :jobFilter)
),
limited_builds AS (
  SELECT job, build, timestamp, anomaly_count
  FROM ranked_builds WHERE rn <= :buildCount
)
SELECT * FROM limited_builds ORDER BY timestamp

      Response Format:

      Returns ChartDataDTO containing:

      • labels: Build identifiers for X-axis (e.g., "my-web-app - Build ‚Ññ 123")
      • datasets: Array with single dataset for anomaly count trends

      Chart Data Structure:

      • X-axis (labels): Job name + build number combinations
      • Y-axis (data): Anomaly counts for each build
      • Series: Single dataset "Anomaly Count" with blue color (#36A2EB)
      • Ordering: Chronological by timestamp for trend visualization

      Build Count Validation:

      • Null or < 1 defaults to 5 builds
      • Maximum capped at 15 builds for performance
      • Applied per job when jobFilter = "all"
      • Ensures manageable chart data size

      Label Generation:

      • Format: "{job} - Build ‚Ññ {build}"
      • Preserves job name and build number for identification
      • Chronological ordering for trend analysis
      • Consistent formatting across all chart endpoints

      Trend Analysis Capabilities:

      • Shows anomaly count changes over time
      • Helps identify patterns and improvement trends
      • Useful for tracking security posture over time
      • Enables comparison between different time periods

      Use Cases:

      • Dashboard trend charts and visualizations
      • Historical analysis of build quality
      • Performance tracking and improvement monitoring
      • Executive reporting on security trends

      Example Usage:

      GET /api/dashboard/anomaly-trend?jobFilter=my-web-app&buildCount=10
GET /api/dashboard/anomaly-trend?jobFilter=all&buildCount=7
      Parameters:
      jobFilter - the job name to filter by, or "all" for all jobs
      buildCount - the number of recent builds to include in the trend analysis
      Returns:
      ChartDataDTO containing formatted data for anomaly trend visualization
      See Also:
      • ChartDataDTO
      • DatasetDTO
      • DashboardService.getAnomalyTrend(String, Integer)

    • getSeverityDistribution

      @GetMapping("/severity-distribution") public ChartDataDTO getSeverityDistribution(@RequestParam(defaultValue="all") String jobFilter, @RequestParam(defaultValue="5") Integer buildCount)
      Retrieves anomaly severity distribution data for chart visualization.

      Database Query Process:

      1. Queries build_anomaly_summary table for severity analysis
      2. Uses same CTE structure as anomaly trend for build selection
      3. Extracts severity_counts JSONB field containing severity distribution
      4. Processes severity data for each build in the result set
      5. Aggregates severity counts across selected builds
      6. Returns structured data for stacked chart visualization

      Endpoint: GET /api/dashboard/severity-distribution

      Query Parameters:

      • jobFilter: Job name or "all" for all jobs (default: "all")
      • buildCount: Number of recent builds to analyze (default: 5, max: 15)

      Response Format:

      Returns ChartDataDTO containing:

      • labels: Build identifiers for X-axis
      • datasets: Multiple data series, one for each severity level

      Severity Levels & Colors:

      Data is broken down by severity categories with consistent colors:

      • CRITICAL: Severe security or system issues (red #FF6384)
      • HIGH: Important issues requiring attention (orange #FF9F40)
      • MEDIUM: Moderate issues to be addressed (yellow #FFCD56)
      • WARNING: Minor issues or potential problems (blue #36A2EB)
      • LOW: Informational or low-priority issues (purple #9966FF)

      JSONB Severity Processing:

      • severity_counts field contains JSONB object with severity breakdown
      • Each build's severity data is parsed and aggregated
      • Missing severity levels default to 0 count
      • Data structured for stacked bar chart visualization

      Chart Visualization:

      • Stacked Bar Chart: Shows severity breakdown per build
      • Color-coded Series: Easy severity identification
      • Consistent Colors: Same color scheme across dashboard
      • Multiple Views: Supports both absolute counts and percentage views

      Analysis Insights:

      • Identify builds with high-severity issues
      • Track improvement in security posture over time
      • Compare severity patterns across different jobs
      • Prioritize remediation efforts based on severity trends

      Data Processing Logic:

      • Iterates through build data to extract severity information
      • Maintains separate data arrays for each severity level
      • Ensures consistent ordering across all severity datasets
      • Handles missing or null severity data gracefully

      Use Cases:

      • Security dashboard severity breakdown charts
      • Quality assurance trend analysis
      • Risk assessment and prioritization
      • Team performance and improvement tracking

      Example Usage:

      GET /api/dashboard/severity-distribution?jobFilter=backend-service&buildCount=8
GET /api/dashboard/severity-distribution?jobFilter=all&buildCount=12
      Parameters:
      jobFilter - the job name to filter by, or "all" for all jobs
      buildCount - the number of recent builds to include in the distribution analysis
      Returns:
      ChartDataDTO containing formatted data for severity distribution visualization
      See Also:
      • ChartDataDTO
      • DatasetDTO
      • DashboardService.getSeverityDistribution(String, Integer)

    • getAiInsights

      @GetMapping("/builds/{conversationId}/{buildNumber}/ai-insights") public Map<String,Object> getAiInsights(@PathVariable String conversationId, @PathVariable Integer buildNumber)
      Retrieves AI-generated insights for a specific build.

      Database Query Process:

      1. Queries chat_messages table for AI analysis results
      2. Filters WHERE message_type = 'ASSISTANT' AND conversation_id = :conversationId AND build_number = :buildNumber
      3. Extracts JSONB content field containing comprehensive AI analysis
      4. Parses insights, recommendations, and analysis data
      5. Returns structured response with AI insights or error information

      Endpoint: GET /api/dashboard/builds/{conversationId}/{buildNumber}/ai-insights

      Path Parameters:

      • conversationId: The Jenkins job name (conversation identifier)
      • buildNumber: The specific build number to get insights for

      Response Structure:

      Returns a Map containing AI insights such as:

      • hasData: Boolean indicating if AI insights are available
      • data: Comprehensive AI analysis results (if available)
      • message: Error or status message (if data unavailable)

      AI Insights Data Structure (when available):

      • Build Analysis: Overall build health and performance assessment
      • Quality Metrics: Code quality, test coverage, and technical debt analysis
      • Security Assessment: Vulnerability analysis and security recommendations
      • Performance Insights: Build time analysis and optimization suggestions
      • Recommendations: Actionable steps for improvement
      • Trend Analysis: Comparison with previous builds and historical data

      AI Analysis Components:

      • Log Pattern Analysis: Automated log parsing and anomaly detection
      • Test Result Evaluation: Test failure analysis and coverage assessment
      • Dependency Scanning: Security vulnerability scanning results
      • Code Quality Metrics: Static analysis and quality violations
      • Performance Regression: Build time and performance trend detection
      • Best Practice Compliance: Industry standard compliance assessment

      JSONB Content Processing:

      • AI analysis stored as structured JSONB in content field
      • Complex nested objects with insights, metrics, and recommendations
      • Graceful handling of missing or malformed AI data
      • Error logging for failed content parsing attempts

      Use Cases:

      • Detailed build analysis and troubleshooting
      • Quality assurance and code review processes
      • Performance optimization and improvement planning
      • Security assessment and vulnerability management

      Data Availability:

      • AI insights are generated asynchronously after build completion
      • Analysis may take several minutes for complex builds
      • If hasData is false, analysis may still be in progress
      • Retry mechanism recommended for pending analyses
      Parameters:
      conversationId - the Jenkins job name (conversation identifier)
      buildNumber - the specific build number to get AI insights for
      Returns:
      Map containing comprehensive AI-generated insights and analysis
      See Also:
      • DashboardService.getAiInsights(String, Integer)

    • getJobs

      @GetMapping("/job-explorer") public List<Map<String,Object>> getJobs(@RequestParam(required=false) String tab)
      Retrieves Jenkins jobs filtered by status for the job explorer interface.

      Database Query Process:

      1. Queries chat_messages table for job status information
      2. Uses complex CTE to get latest build status per job
      3. Filters by status using CASE WHEN logic for status classification
      4. Joins with Jenkins API data for real-time job information
      5. Returns comprehensive job list with metadata

      Endpoint: GET /api/dashboard/job-explorer

      Query Parameters:

      • tab: Status filter for jobs (optional, default: "all")

      Supported Status Filters:

      • "all": All jobs regardless of status
      • "success": Jobs with successful recent builds
      • "failure": Jobs with failed recent builds
      • "unstable": Jobs with unstable recent builds
      • "aborted": Jobs with aborted recent builds
      • "disabled": Disabled or inactive jobs

      Status Classification Logic:

      • Success: Latest build completed without significant anomalies
      • Failure: Latest build failed or has critical anomalies
      • Unstable: Build succeeded but has warnings or medium anomalies
      • Aborted: Build was manually stopped or cancelled
      • Disabled: Job is disabled in Jenkins or has no recent activity

      Response Format:

      Returns a List of Maps, each containing job information such as:

      • jobName: Name of the Jenkins job
      • status: Current build status and health classification
      • lastBuild: Information about the most recent build
      • buildHistory: Summary of recent build results
      • healthScore: Overall job health assessment (0-100)
      • anomalyCount: Number of anomalies in recent builds
      • lastActivity: Timestamp of last build activity

      Data Integration:

      • Database Analysis: AI analysis results and anomaly data
      • Jenkins API: Real-time job status and configuration
      • Computed Metrics: Health scores and trend analysis
      • Status Mapping: Consistent status classification across sources

      Job Explorer Features:

      • Tabbed Interface: Filter jobs by status categories
      • Health Indicators: Visual health status and trend information
      • Quick Actions: Direct links to job details and build history
      • Bulk Operations: Support for bulk job management operations

      Use Cases:

      • Job management and administration interfaces
      • System health monitoring and overview
      • Troubleshooting and issue identification
      • Team productivity and performance analysis

      Example Usage:

      GET /api/dashboard/job-explorer?tab=failure
GET /api/dashboard/job-explorer?tab=success
GET /api/dashboard/job-explorer
      Parameters:
      tab - the status filter to apply (optional, defaults to "all")
      Returns:
      List of Maps containing job information filtered by status
      See Also:
      • DashboardService.getJobsByStatus(String)
